caption: (Translated by Google) Very good quality for Dominican food. It is noted that the ingredients are more expensive and of quality.  (Original) Muy buena calidad para comida dominicana. Se nota que los ingredientes son más caros y de calidad.
Amazing food, was in the mood for some Dominican food and this place really hit the spot . I recommend the Yaroa you won’t be disappointed.
I ordered a 3 golpe, and I wish I can get my $16 back! It was horrible my salami literally still had the wrap on it still....Honestly it was disgusting and disappointing!

Horrible service. You have to wait a long time to place an order. They are always out of most things in their menu!. The women that work their have nasty attitudes, the only nice one there is the male chef. FYI if you want your buisness to succeed at least have good customer service skills.
This place is so awesome and the food is so delicious.

The Shrimp Empanada wow-ed me at my first visit for it's flavor and texture; second time was much less in flavor (you can tell from my photos) it's still good for its value $2.5 but I hope they keep up the quality.  Beef Empanada was pretty good as well $2 is a steal.

I LOVE THIS SPOT! Their empanadas are so delicious and for a good price. If you gotta pick, get their chicken, beef, or ham and cheese! My sister had the tres golpes platter and was a fan too. Very nice people!

First time visit to the stall in the new Essex Street Market. Came at my wife's suggestion while in this part of town to visit a doctor. Loved the overall space of the market's new digs. In particular I enjoyed my interactions with the staff at Dominican Cravings, the young lady helping me was patient explaining what was what as I'm not Dominican (if you can't tell from the pic I'm just another middle aged white guy). I had not had any breakfast so I tried the mangú, which was mashed plantains with fried salami, fried cheese and eggs. As a transplant from the American South it fit my dietary preferences for fat fried and greasy, health nuts need not even bother. All the empanadas from here are great, I think I've tried all the flavors by now (my wife has picked them up and brought them home before.
I just bought Tostones and I was thinking it was wasn’t going to be a lot but when I saw how much Tostones there was I was shocked. Definitely was worth my $3.27
The food is great fast service great customers service the patacon and lemon juice is the best also the chimi and empanadas and the mori soñando / diedreming juice is one of my favorite

Dominican Cravings serves up a selection of comfort foods within the new Essex Market. stall #49, close to the Broome St side of the new Essex Market, 88 Essex Street.  it's a brand new looking space. very clean. empanadas and soft drinks viewable in front. small kitchen/grill behind the counter. there is small order counter which accepts cash + debit & credit cards.  the food? good to very good.  the empanadas are priced around $2.50 + tax. the cheeseburger empanada is the way to go: cheesy, meaty in a crispy shell. and the shrimp empanada is also a nice option.  the chicken Chimi is a sauce-dripping long roll sandwich filled with chunks on seasoned grilled chicken and topped with shredded cabbage. the soft long roll is perfect to cradle this savory sandwich. $7 + tax  also Dominican Cravings serves a traditional Dominican breakfast. a platter of mangu, salami, quesofrito, etc. the problem? they open at 11 am and serve it for less than an hour. lol. why not serve it all day?  a variety of patacons are also served here.  the service is pretty good and fast. it's inconsistent though. sometimes you get the dipping sauce with empanadas. other times you don't. sometimes they charge tax. sometimes they don't. AND the last time I was here the staff seemed to be arguing with one another and a bunch of customers including myself were kept waiting while they sussed that all out. not super professional imo, but the food is so good so whatevz.  drops mic cuz i'm toasting' with these tostones
